questions.text: Which of the following combinations correctly describes the effect on Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) given the status of the afferent and efferent arterioles?

options.label: D
options.text: Efferent arteriole mild constriction - GFR increased

questions.correct_answer: D. Efferent arteriole mild constriction - GFR increased
questions.explanation:
Arteriole Change

Effect on Resistance

Effect on Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure

Effect on GFR

Afferent Arteriole Constriction

Increases

Decreases

Decreases

Afferent Arteriole Dilation

Decreases

Increases

Increases

Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Mild

Increases

Increases

Slight increase

Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Severe

Increases

Increases
  • Initially increases GFR then ultimately decreases.
  • Severe efferent arteriole constriction reduces renal blood flow and increases filtration fraction, concentrating plasma proteins in the glomerular capillaries and elevating glomerular colloid osmotic pressure.
  • This counteracts the effect of increased hydrostatic pressure, ultimately reducing GFR

Efferent Arteriole Dilation

Decreases

Decreases

Decreases

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the effect of food additives on GFR in order to determine what additives should be avoided in individuals with CKD. Caffeine was found to affect urine output through an effect on GFR. What is the effect and the mechanism involved?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation

options.label: B
options.text: Increase urine output; efferent arteriole vasodilation

options.label: C
options.text: Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasoconstriction

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is admitted to the ED with an acute myocardial infarction. The man was transferred to the CCU and was placed on 24 h intake and output. A few days later his 24 hr urinary output was decreased. An increase in which of the following contributes to the reduced urine flow in a patient with congestive heart failure?
Which of the following best describes what happens to the PAH excretion rate when the plasma concentration of PAH exceeds the transport maximum (Tm)?

options.label: A
options.text: The excretion rate continues to increase linearly with increasing plasma concentration upto a certain level.

options.label: B
options.text: The excretion rate reaches a plateau and remains constant despite further increases in plasma concentration beyond a level..

options.label: C
options.text: The excretion rate decreases with increasing plasma concentration.

options.label: D
options.text: The excretion rate first increases linearly, then decreases after reaching the transport maximum.

questions.correct_answer: B. The excretion rate reaches a plateau and remains constant despite further increases in plasma concentration beyond a level..

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the juxtaglomerular (JG) apparatus?
Which of the following best explains the relationship between creatinine clearance (CrCl) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Creatinine clearance is a direct measure of GFR.

options.label: B
options.text: Creatinine clearance is an indirect measure of GFR and typically overestimates GFR.

options.label: C
options.text: Creatinine clearance underestimates GFR because it accounts for tubular secretion of creatinine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Creatinine clearance is an indirect measure of GFR and typically overestimates GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "free water clearance" (C H2O ) is correct? Free water clearance = C H2O Urine osmolality = U osm Plasma osmolality = P osm Urine flow rate = V̇

options.label: A
options.text: Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypotonic and negative when the urine is hypertonic.

options.label: B
options.text: Free water clearance is the same as urine flow rate (V̇).

options.label: C
options.text: Free water clearance is calculated using C H2O = U osm (V̇)/ P osm.

options.label: D
options.text: Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypertonic and negative when the urine is hypotonic.

questions.correct_answer: A. Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypotonic and negative when the urine is hypertonic.

questions.text: A patient's hematocrit (the fraction of blood volume occupied by red blood cells) is 40%. The patient's renal plasma flow (RPF) is measured to be 600 mL/min. What is this patient's renal blood flow (RBF)?
Why is inulin clearance the gold standard for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Inulin is readily available and naturally produced in the body

options.label: B
options.text: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of GFR.

options.label: C
options.text: Inulin has a high plasma concentration that enhances measurement accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: Inulin is rapidly metabolised by the kidneys, making it easier to measure

questions.correct_answer: B. Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of GFR.

questions.text: A patient has a urine concentration of a substance of 10 mg/mL, a urine flow rate of 2 mL/min, and a plasma concentration of that substance of 5 mg/mL. What is the clearance rate of this substance?
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with severe renal artery stenosis is admitted for hypertension management. The physician decides to prescribe a medication to control the blood pressure but must avoid drugs that could adversely affect kidney function due to the existing renal impairment. Which drug is contraindicated in this patient due to the risk of worsening renal function?
Which of the following is NOT an effect of angiotensin II?

options.label: A
options.text: Constriction of efferent arterioles in the kidneys

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules
questions.explanation:
1

Renal Tubular Reabsorption

Directly increases sodium reabsorption in proximal tubules, loops of Henle, distal tubules, and collecting tubules. (Option B)

2

Vasoconstriction

Angiotensin II constricts arterioles, especially efferent arterioles in the kidneys, increasing glomerular pressure and maintaining GFR even at low blood pressure. (Option A)

3

Aldosterone Secretion

Stimulates adrenal cortex to release aldosterone, enhancing sodium and water retention in the kidneys. (Option C)

4

Baroreflex Sensitivity

Reduces baroreflex sensitivity in the brain, boosting its effects on blood pressure.

5

Thirst and Hormone Secretion

Increases thirst, stimulates vasopressin (ADH) release for water reabsorption, and triggers ACTH secretion. (Option D)

6

Mesangial Cells

Causes contraction of mesangial cells, potentially reducing GFR by decreasing filtration surface area

7

System Interactions

Effects are influenced by sodium intake, blood volume, and other hormones. Active during low sodium or volume depletion to maintain GFR and fluid balance.

questions.text: All of the following increase GFR except:
questions.explanation:
Mediator

Effect on GFR

Additional Notes

Prostaglandins (PGE2, PGI2) (Option D)

Increase

Cause vasodilation; especially important in counteracting vasoconstriction from sympathetic nerves or angiotensin II

Bradykinin (Option A)

Increase

Functions similarly to prostaglandins by causing vasodilation

Nitric Oxide (Option B)

Increases

Important for maintaining normal renal excretion of sodium and water; decreased production linked to hypertension

Angiotensin II

Biphasic effect on GFR

Constricts efferent arterioles, increasing glomerular pressure; severe constriction decreases GFR ​

Sympathetic Nerves (Option C)

Decrease

Cause vasoconstriction, especially under stress or volume depletion

Norepinephrine, Epinephrine, Endothelin

Decreases

Vasoconstriction

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nephrons is correct? Total renal blood flow rate is 1000 to 1260 ml/minute Tubular reabsorption is the first step in urine production Chronic kidney disease occurs when there is a 75% reduction in the original number of nephrons. The cortical region of the kidney is most vulnerable to ischemia. Nephrons can regenerate after age 40. Maintains Acid-Base balance by secreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate.
questions.explanation:
Nephrons

Structural and functional units of the kidney

Number per Kidney

0.8 to 1.2 million (average of 1 million)

Length

4.5 to 6.5 cm (average of 5 cm)

Renal Blood Flow
  • Total Blood Flow Rate: 1000 to 1260 ml/minute (20 to 25% of cardiac output)
  • Blood Flow Distribution: Cortex: 90%, Medulla: 10%
  • Vulnerability to Ischemia: The Medulla is prone to ischemia; the Corticomedullary junction is more vulnerable
  • Plasma Flow Rate: 625 to 700 ml/minute through both kidneys combined

Nephron Function
  • Glomerular Filtration: First step in urine formation; filters water, ions, and small molecules from blood into Bowman's capsule
  • Tubular Reabsorption: Process where the nephron removes water and solutes from the filtrate and returns them to the blood
  • Tubular Secretion: Transfer of materials from blood into the tubular fluid
  • Excretion: Final elimination of urine from the body

Additional Functions
  • Regulation of Blood Pressure: By controlling blood volume through reabsorption and secretion mechanisms
  • Acid-Base Balance: By secreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate
  • Electrolyte Balance: By reabsorbing and secreting electrolytes such as sodium, potassium, calcium, and magnesium
  • Erythropoietin Production: A hormone that stimulates red blood cell production in the bone marrow, especially in response to low oxygen levels in the blood

Age-Specific Dynamics of Nephron
  • Nephrons cannot regenerate.
  • Nephron count decreases by 10% every 10 year after age 40.
  • By age 80, about 40% of nephrons remain functional.
  • Chronic kidney disease occurs when there is a 70 to 75% reduction in the original number of nephrons.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for Myogenic Autoregulation of renal blood flow?
Calculate Renal Plasma Flow (RPF) if the GFR is 125 ml/min and the Filtration Fraction (FF) is 0.2.
Calculate the Net Filtration Pressure from the values given below: Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure = 60 mmHg Bowman’s Capsule Pressure = 18 mmHg Glomerular Colloid Osmotic Pressure = 32 mmHg
If the molecular radius of a substance is 3.0 nm, it is known as:
questions.explanation:
Type of substance

Molecular radius

Explanation

Examples

Freely filtrable

<1.8 nm

Easily pass through the barrier

  • Potassium
  • Water
  • Urea
  • Creatinine
  • Inulin
  • PAH
  • Bicarbonate

Selectively permeable

The charge on them determines filtration
  • Albumin
  • Haemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Bence Jones proteins

Impermeable

>4.2 nm

It cannot be filtered

questions.explanation:
Protein

Disease

Nephrin

Podocin

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not a part of the glomerular filtration barrier

options.label: D
options.text: Charges of substances do not affect their permeability through GBM

questions.correct_answer: C. Excludes substances larger than 8 nm
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Structure

A specialized membrane forming a sheath shared by neighboring capillaries

Contents
  • Fine fibrils in a gel-like matrix
  • The matrix contains type 4 collagen, laminin, fibronectin, and other negatively charged proteins

Permeability
  • Permits free passage of neutral substances up to 4 nm in diameter
  • Excludes substances larger than 8 nm

Molecular Charge Influence

Charge on molecules affects their passage into Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary site of action of acetazolamide in the nephron?
Which of the following characteristics correctly differentiates the Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) from the Collecting Duct (CT)?

options.label: A
options.text: Paracellular transport present in CT and not in PCT

options.label: B
options.text: Brush border of epithelium present in PCT, not in CT

options.label: C
options.text: Tight junctions are tight in PCT and leaky in CT

options.label: D
options.text: Carbonic anhydrase type 4 absent in PCT, but present in CT

questions.correct_answer: B. Brush border of epithelium present in PCT, not in CT
questions.explanation:
Feature

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Collecting Duct (CT)

Epithelium Type

Simple cuboidal with brush border

Simple cuboidal to columnar without brush border

Brush Border

Present

Absent

Microvilli

Dense microvilli (forming brush border)

Absent microvilli

Paracellular Transport

Significant due to leaky tight junctions

Minimal due to tight tight junctions

Tight Junctions

Leaky

Tight

Carbonic Anhydrase Type 4

Present in microvilli

Generally absent

Mitochondrial Density

High

Lower than PCT

Transport Mechanisms

Active and passive

Primarily passive

Reabsorption of Glucose

Almost complete

Minimal

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents with symptoms of fatigue, fluid retention, and low serum potassium levels. On examination, the patient shows signs of hypertension and oedema. Which of the following types of cells being defective in the renal tubules is responsible for the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Functions

Characteristics

Principal Cells

(Option A)
  • Sodium reabsorption
  • Potassium secretion
  • Water reabsorption
  • Responsive to aldosterone
  • ADH receptors
  • Columnar epithelium

Alpha Intercalated Cells

(Option B)
  • Secrete H⁺ ions
  • Reabsorb bicarbonate
  • Apical H⁺-ATPases
  • Cuboidal epithelium

Beta Intercalated Cells

(Option C)
  • Secrete bicarbonate
  • Reabsorb H⁺ ions
  • Apical bicarbonate transporters
  • Cuboidal epithelium

questions.text: Which part of the proximal tubule is the most vulnerable and prone to ischemia?
questions.explanation:
S1

S2

S3

Location

Proximal to the glomerulus.

Between S1 and S3.

Near the loop of Henle.

Function

Reabsorption of nutrients, ions, and water.

Reabsorption of water, ions, and bicarbonate.

Reabsorption of sodium, bicarbonate, and nutrients.

Features

High brush border density.

A brush border is present but less extensive than S1.

High mitochondrial density.

Risk of ischaemia

Least prone

Intermediate

Most prone

questions.text: Match each component of the countercurrent system with its respective function: Components Functions 1. Ascending Limb of Loop of Henle a. Blood loses water and gains solutes as it passes through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. 2. Descending Limb of Loop of Henle b. Blood gains water and loses solutes as it passes through the less concentrated interstitium. 3. Ascending Vasa Recta c. Actively transports sodium and chloride into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate. 4. Descending Vasa Recta d. Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate.
questions.explanation:
Countercurrent Multiplier System

Countercurrent Exchanger System

Location: Loop of Henle

Location: Vasa Recta

Function: Creates an osmotic gradient in the renal medulla to concentrate urine

Function: Maintains the osmotic gradient established by the countercurrent multiplier system and supplies nutrients to the medulla

Descending Limb: Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate

Descending Vasa Recta: Blood loses water, and gains solute as it descends through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium

Ascending Limb: Impermeable to water; actively transports sodium and chloride out into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate

Ascending Vasa Recta: Blood gains water and loses solutes as it ascends through the less concentrated interstitium.

Mechanism: Countercurrent flow between descending and ascending limbs multiplies the osmotic gradient, enabling the concentration of urine

Mechanism: Countercurrent exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the surrounding interstitium preserves the osmotic gradient

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between cortical and juxtamedullary nephrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Cortical nephrons have longer loops of Henle.

options.label: B
options.text: Juxtamedullary nephrons constitute approximately 85% in the kidney.

options.label: C
options.text: Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Juxtamedullary nephrons are located primarily in the renal cortex, whereas cortical nephrons are in the renal medulla.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cortical Nephrons

Juxtamedullary Nephrons

Location

Renal cortex.

Near the boundary between the renal cortex and medulla.

Percentage of Total Nephrons

Approximately 85%

Approximately 15%

Loop of Henle

Short and extends only into the outer medulla.

Long and extends deep into the inner medulla.

Vasa Recta

Short and less extensive.

Long vasa recta, which follows the loop of Henle into the medulla.

Glomerular Capsule

Has a larger surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle.

Smaller surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle.

Filtration Rate

High

Lower filtration rate but more specialised in concentration.

Presence of Macula Densa

Typically not present.

These nephrons are closely associated with the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

Function

Primarily involved in regulating blood composition and volume through reabsorption and secretion.
  • Concentration of urine due to the longer loops and extensive vasa recta
  • Contributing to the medullary osmotic gradient.
